messages.subject: Re: umabari and horses
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ken,  thanks for the site -- the description of the umabari with the tool sold really privides a piece of the puzzle. And Jim Gilbert s observation that
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ken, thanks for the site -- the description of the umabari with
the tool sold really privides a piece of the puzzle.

And Jim Gilbert's observation that kogai and kozuka were mainly found
on the mountings for more treasured swords, which for the most part
are the ones that survived, makes sense. My sayashi friend says it
would realy add the $$ if someone wanted him to make a saya with
carve outs for those tools.

Are there any examples of kogai or kozuka mounted on a tachi?? Any
idea when these tools first began to appear?? Trying to get a
complete picture of a 14th century samurai is tough. Especially for
the lower samurai ranks, and the lowly ashigaru with their naginata,
yari, and uchikatanna. Sure is fun though.

as an aside, i also am glad Jim Kurrasch's site is still up. Lots of
good stuff there.

thanks for the help with my minor mystery, guys.

doug e.
In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Kenneth Wilson <kdw21620@y...>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: umabari and horses
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, I had the same sort of intuition, but my understanding is that this was not exactly a precision therapeutic treatment.  It was more a matter of getting
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
I had the same sort of intuition, but my understanding is that this was not exactly a precision therapeutic treatment. It was more a matter of getting an exhausted horse to run a few more miles. I think we'll need to find an Asian specialist in large animal veterinary with an interest in historical methods to make progress on this one.

Jim

jim und all,
I think it's a wee bit too big for acupunture.
OTOH, the novice acupunturist would not miss any " energy points "
with a big needle like that...........
=)

-m
